slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the role of permissions in controlling
user capabilities in ClaimCenter

• Describe the use of roles in managing user
permissions

« Assign permissions to roles

• Assign roles to users

• Describe Access Control Lists (ACLs)

slides.title: Access
slides.originalNotes:
Access
ClaimCenter uses the users’ identity to control their ability to act on or even see claim objects. Access control manages all levels of access including creation, modification and deletion of objects. It also controls ownership, visibility, and what a user can do with an object, like closing a claim. The base of this access control is system permissions, which determine what a user can and cannot do.
slides.notes:
Access
ClaimCenter uses the users’ identity to control their ability to act on or even see claim objects. Access control manages all levels of access including creation, modification and deletion of objects. It also controls ownership, visibility, and what a user can do with an object, like closing a claim. The base of this access control is system permissions, which determine what a user can and cannot do.
slides.ocrText:
| Access G&G

Access is the ability to see and do things in ClaimCenter based on your user
identity

Access can control

* Creation, modification, or deletion

* Ownership
+ Visibility (viewing and navigation)

+ What you can do with an object (i.e., close claim)
Access is granted and managed with system permissions

Permissions determine what a user can and cannot do

slides.title: Auser's permissions are determined d
slides.originalNotes:
A user's permissions are determined during login (2 of 4)
ClaimCenter queries its database to authenticate the user and determine which permissions are assigned to the user and the user's start page.

In the base application, authentication is managed through the ClaimCenter database. The system can also be configured to authenticate against an existing user domain structure.

Permissions determine which screens the user can navigate to and which actions the user can perform. The startup view is the first page rendered after log inand can be set by the user in their user profile.

slides.title: Auser's permissions are determined during login
slides.originalNotes:
A user's permissions are determined during login (3 of 4)
If the user is authenticated, they are granted access to ClaimCenter based on the permissions given to their username. Those permissions will be used to determine which screens they may access and what actions they may take on claims. This phase also returns which view is their default startup view.

A user's permissions are determined during login (4 of 4)
ClaimCenter then renders the users' startup view with the permissions assigned to that user.
Permissions are initially determined at login. However, if an administrator changes a useNspermissions while that user is logged in, the new permissions are applied immediately.

slides.title: Permissions
slides.originalNotes:
Permissions
System permissions are used to restrict what a user can do.

In this example there are 3 users; Rick is a manager, Betty is an adjuster, and Ida is a customer service representative. Rick an Betty have been granted the view team permission which gives them access to team information. Ida does not need to see team information so she does not have the view team permission. Rick and Betty can create address book contacts which is something they may do occasionally, but that is not something that a CSR should do, so Ida does not have that permission. Likewise, as a CSR, Ida should not be the owner of a claim or be able to close a claim, so she does not have those permissions while Rick and Betty do
slides.notes:

Likewise, as a CSR, Ida should not be the owner of a claim or be able to close a claim, so she does not have those permissions while Rick and Betty do

slides.title: Assigning permissions to roles
slides.originalNotes:
Assigning permissions to roles
There are quite a few system permissions. Assigning each user the exact permissions they need would be a very large and detailed task. ClaimCenter has the concept of roles which are named collections of permissions which can be granted to multiple users.
For example, the CSR role has view and create claims, edit claims and exposures, and so on. CSRs don't need to edit matters or own claims, so the CSR role does not have those system permissions. The Adjuster role has everything the CSR role has, plus a few others.

There are a couple of ways you can use roles to accommodate this structure. You could create the Adjuster role so it has all the permissions of the CSR role the additional permissions. In thiscase, CSR users get just the CSR role and adjusters get only the adjuster role.

You could also create the adjuster role, so it has only the additional permissions that CSRs do not get. CSR users would get only the CSR role, while Adjusters would then get both the CSR and the adjuster role.
slides.notes:
Assigning permissions to roles
There are quite a few system permissions. Assigning each user the exact permissions they need would be a very large and detailed task. ClaimCenter has the concept of roles which are named collections of permissions which can be granted to multiple users.
For example, the CSR role has view and create claims, edit claims and exposures, and so on. CSRs don't need to edit matters or own claims, so the CSR role does not have those system permissions. The Adjuster role has everything the CSR role has, plus a few others.

There are a couple of ways you can use roles to accommodate this structure. You could create the Adjuster role so it has all the permissions of the CSR role the additional permissions. In thiscase, CSR users get just the CSR role and adjusters get only the adjuster role.

You could also create the adjuster role, so it has only the additional permissions that CSRs do not get. CSR users would get only the CSR role, while Adjusters would then get both the CSR and the adjuster role.

slides.title: Assigning roles to users
slides.originalNotes:
Assigning roles to users
In this example, Ida Belt is a CSR, and therefore has all the permissions of a CSR through the CSR role. Betty is an adjuster, and therefore has all the permissions of an adjuster through the Adjuster role. Rick is a manager, and therefore has all the permissions of a manager, which include the permissions in the Adjuster role and the Manager role.

ClaimCenter permissions only grant the ability to do something. ClaimCenter does not have any permissions that specifically deny a user the ability to do something. The only way to prevent someone from having a given permission is to not assign them any roles with that permission.

You can assign a role to a user from the Administration tab in two ways. You can choose the user and edit the list of roles, or youcan add the user to the role in the
roles screen.
slides.notes:
Assigning roles to users
In this example, Ida Belt is a CSR, and therefore has all the permissions of a CSR through the CSR role. Rick is a manager, and therefore has all the permissions of a manager, which include the permissions in the Adjuster role and the Manager role.

ClaimCenter permissions only grant the ability to do something. ClaimCenter does not have any permissions that specifically deny a user the ability to do something. The only way to prevent someone from having a given permission is to not assign them any roles with that permission.

You can assign a role to a user from the Administration tab in two ways. You can choose the user and edit the list of roles, or youcan add the user to the role in the
roles screen.

slides.title: The security dictionary
slides.originalNotes:
The security dictionary
The security dictionary documents the initial relationship between permissions, roles, and pages. It is an html page and is located in the security\index.html.

The security dictionary lists Application permission keys, which are sets of system permissions, system permissions, which are the lowest level of permissions, and roles, which are used to group and assign application permission keys.

ClaimCenter defines application permission keys internally as a method for improving system performance. For example, the claimedit application permission key contains 2 system permissions which represent the permissions needed for editing a claim: claimedit for open claims, and claim editclsd for closed claims.
slides.notes:

The security dictionary lists Application permission keys, which are sets of system permissions, system permissions, which are the lowest level of permissions, and roles, which are used to group and assign application permission keys.

slides.title: System permissions and application permission
slides.originalNotes:
System permissions and application permission keys
The System Permissions section of the security dictionary lists each permission and for each permission, the roles that contain it, the application permission keys that contain it, and the pages and user interface elements that reference it.

Application Permission keys are used mostly in configuration They simplify the restriction of user interface elements to a specific set of permissions.

Application permission keys are generally used to restrict access to user interface elements. A screen or even a button may be restricted by an application permission key. The Application Permission Keys section of the security dictionary lists each application permission key, the set of system permissions it contains, and the pages and elements in the user interface that use the application permission key.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Access Control Lists (ACLs) add object level
slides.originalNotes:
Access Control Lists (ACLs) add object level permissions
Access Control Lists identify which users can have access to a claim and any of its sub-objects. The primary purpose of the Access Control List feature is to enforce the business requirement that access to claim objects be controlled by more than just permissions. A user that works on auto claims only should not have access to workers' comp claims, regardless of the permissions on their roles.

Access Control Lists are also used to determine who can own, edit, or even view a given type of claim
slides.notes:
Access Control Lists (ACLs) add object level permissions
Access Control Lists identify which users can have access to a claim and any of its sub-objects. The primary purpose of the Access Control List feature is to enforce the business requirement that access to claim objects be controlled by more than just permissions. A user that works on auto claims only should not have access to workers' comp claims, regardless of the permissions on their roles.

Access Control Lists are also used to determine who can own, edit, or even view a given type of claim

slides.title: Permissions versus ACLs
slides.originalNotes:
Permissions versus ACLs
Permissions may be static or object-based. For example, create group is a static permission meaning that a user with that permission can always create a group without any restriction. Static permissions are granted across the entire application and are an all-or-none approach.

Create exposure is an object- based permission because it does not use an all-or-none approach. A user with create exposure permissions can create exposures only on those claims to which they have access. For example, an auto adjuster does not have access to workers’ comp claims and therefore cannot create exposures on workers' comp claims, regardless of having the create exposure permission.

For a user to create an exposure, they must have the create exposure permission and have access to the claim. Access Control Lists and permissions work together to increase the level of access security.
slides.notes:
Permissions versus ACLs
Permissions may be static or object-based. For example, create group is a static permission meaning that a user with that permission can always create a group without any restriction. Static permissions are granted across the entire application and are an all-or-none approach.

Create exposure is an object- based permission because it does not use an all-or-none approach. A user with create exposure permissions can create exposures only on those claims to which they have access. For example, an auto adjuster does not have access to workers’ comp claims and therefore cannot create exposures on workers' comp claims, regardless of having the create exposure permission.

For a user to create an exposure, they must have the create exposure permission and have access to the claim. Access Control Lists and permissions work together to increase the level of access security.

slides.title: Permissions and ACLs
slides.originalNotes:
Permissions and ACLs
To view or act on a claim, a user must have the appropriate permission as well as appear on the claim's Access Control List. In this example, Andy Applegate has view claim system permission and is on the Access Control List for this claim. Therefore, Andy can view this claim. Jason Tran also has the view claim system permission, but he is not listed on the Access Control List for the claim, therefore, he cannot view claim. Perhaps Jason is an adjuster for workers' comp claims and therefore does not need access to auto claims.

Ida is listed on the Access Control List as someone who can view the claim. However, she does not have the view claim system permission, therefore, she also cannot view claim. In fact, since she does not have the view claim permission, Ida cannot view any claim regardless the Access Control List for the claim.
slides.notes:

slides.title: How ACLs are created
slides.originalNotes:
How ACLs are created
Access Control Lists are virtual in that they are created and maintained by ClaimCenter at runtime and there is no user interface to see them. You only see the behavior of the lists.

Access Control Lists are created based on several attributes of a claim or claim object. The security type of the claim, like employee claim, sensitive, and so on, can control who is allowed to work on the claim. Ownership of the claim affects who can see it based on the group to which the owner belongs.

A claim may have a security type specified which is one of theproperties that restrict access to the claim. In the base application, ClaimCenter has several security types. An Employee Claim— A claim covering one of your coworkers, Fraud Risk, Sensitive —A claim you would like to keep out of the public eye, Under Litigation, and Unsecured.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Elements of access control
slides.originalNotes:
Elements of access control
Access Control Lists are determined by an access profile which is in the security-config.xml file. Each security type (employee claim, fraud risk, and so on) has a matching access profile. When the owner of a claim sets the Special Claim Permission to a specific profile, the Access Control List for that claim is created based on that profile. The profile includes what type of access a user should get, like own, view, or edit, and which user should get access which is determined by the user, group, security zone or anyone.
slides.notes:
Elements of access control
Access Control Lists are determined by an access profile which is in the security-config.xml file. Each security type (employee claim, fraud risk, and so on) has a matching access profile. When the owner of a claim sets the Special Claim Permission to a specific profile, the Access Control List for that claim is created based on that profile. The profile includes what type of access a user should get, like own, view, or edit, and which user should get access which is determined by the user, group, security zone or anyone.

slides.title: Access profile I
slides.originalNotes:
Access profile
The access profile in this example is for the security level of unsecuredclaim- When a claim is set to unsecured, or none, ClaimCenter creates an Access Control List using this access profile.

In this unsecuredclaim profile, anyone in the same group as the claim owner will be granted view and edit permissions. Anyone in a group which is in the same security zone as the claim owner will also be granted view only permissions. If a user has the role of relateduser, they will be granted view only permissions.
slides.notes:
Access profile
The access profile in this example is for the security level of unsecuredclaim- When a claim is set to unsecured, or none, ClaimCenter creates an Access Control List using this access profile.

In this unsecuredclaim profile, anyone in the same group as the claim owner will be granted view and edit permissions. Anyone in a group which is in the same security zone as the claim owner will also be granted view only permissions. If a user has the role of relateduser, they will be granted view only permissions.

<AccessProfile securitylevel="unsecuredclaim">
<ClaimAccessLevels>

<AccessLevel level=“group" permission="view"/>
<AccessLevel level=“group" permission="edit"/>

<AccessLevel level="securityzone" permission="view"/>

<ClaimUserAccessLevel role="relateduser" level="user" permission="Vview"/>
</ClaimAccessLevels>

For an unsecured claim (unrestricted):
« All object owners have view and edit access
• All users in the same group as the claim owner have view and edit access
• All users in the same security zone as the claim owner have view and edit access
All users with the relateduser role have view only access

slides.title: Owner access
slides.originalNotes:
Owner access
Based on that security profile, Dana has view and edit access to the claim and its sub-objects because she is the claim owner- She also owns an exposure. Peter has view and edit access to the claim and its sub-objects because he is the owner of an activity on the claim. Jason Tran does not have access to the claim because he does not own the claim or any of its exposures or activities and he is not in the Workers' Comp Security Zone.

slides.title: Group access
slides.originalNotes:
Group access
Ellen is in the same group as Dana, the owner of the claim, so she is granted view and edit access to the claim and its sub- objects. Remember in this example the access profile specifies that anyone in the same group as the owner, has view and edit permissions.

slides.title: Security zone access
slides.originalNotes:
Security zone access
Amit is not in the same group as Dana, but he is in the same security zone. The access profile specifies that anyone in the same security zone as the owner is granted view only permissions. Because Amit is in the same security zone, he can view but cannot edit the claim or any of its’ sub-object.
slides.notes:
Security zone access
Amit is not in the same group as Dana, but he is in the same security zone. The access profile specifies that anyone in the same security zone as the owner is granted view only permissions. Because Amit is in the same security zone, he can view but cannot edit the claim or any of its’ sub-object.

slides.title: ‘Bt access al
slides.originalNotes:
Multiple access profiles
There are usually a small number of security profiles because there are a small number of business circumstances which dictate how access to a claim should be restricted. In the base application, there are five security types, each with its own profile. The five types are:

Unsecured claim, which requires no special restrictions
Employee claim, which has been filed by an employee of the carrier
Fraud risk claim, which has a high risk of being fraudulent
Sensitive claim, which is considered sensitive
Under litigation claim, which is currently under litigation

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
When does ClaimCenter determine which permissions a given user has?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo

questionData.question: When does ClaimCenter determine which permissions a given user has?
questionData.answer: ClaimCenter determines the permissions for a given user when that user logs in.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer [a
When does ClaimCenter determine which permissions a given user has?
•
•
ClaimCenter determines the permissions for a given user when that user logs in.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
How many permissions can a given role have?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo

questionData.question: How many permissions can a given role have?
questionData.answer: A role can have any number of permissions, from zero (which would serve no business purpose but is theoretically possible) to all the permissions in the system.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
How many permissions can a given role have?
•
•
Arole can have any number of permissions, from zero (which would serve no
business purpose but is theoretically possible) to all the permissions in the system.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
How many roles can a given user have?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo

questionData.question: How many roles can a given user have?
questionData.answer: A user can theoretically have any number of roles from Zero to all the roles in the system. A user must have at least one role in order to be able to do anything in ClaimCenter. A user who has broader responsibility than another user can be given additional roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer [a
How many roles can a given user have?
•
•
Auser can theoretically have any number of roles from Zero to all the roles in the
system. A user must have at least one role in order to be able to do anything in
ClaimCenter. A user who has broader responsibility than another user can be given
additional roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
How could you easily determine the number of roles that enable users to
create matters?
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo
Gi

questionData.question:
How could you easily determine the number of roles that enable users to
create matters?
questionData.answer:
You could view the create matter permission in the security dictionary to see which
roles contain that permission. Note that this only works for the base product, because
the security dictionary will not update based on any changes that a project team or
security administrator makes to the roles.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer [a
How could you easily determine the number of roles that enable users to
• create matters?
•
•
You could view the create matter permission in the security dictionary to see which
roles contain that permission. Note that this only works for the base product, because
the security dictionary will not update based on any changes that a project team or
security administrator makes to the roles.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Agiven user appears on the access control list for claim 234-22-147282,
but that user cannot view or edit the claim. How could this happen?
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo
Gi

questionData.question:
A given user appears on the access control list for claim 234-22-147282,
but that user cannot view or edit the claim. How could this happen?
questionData.answer:
The user probably lacks the system permission to view and/or edit claims. In order to
view or edit a claim, the user must have the system permission and appear on the
ACL.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer [a
Agiven user appears on the access control list for claim 234-22-147282,
but that user cannot view or edit the claim. How could this happen?
The user probably lacks the system permission to view and/or edit claims. In order to
view or edit a claim, the user must have the system permission and appear on the
ACL.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Asecurity profile can specify criteria for three types of access. What are
the three types of access?
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo
Gi

questionData.question:
A security profile can specify criteria for three types of access. What are
the three types of access?
questionData.answer: Own access, view access, edit access.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
Asecurity profile can specify criteria for three types of access. What are
the three types of access?
Own access, view access, edit access.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo
Gi

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Two different claims that use the same security profile can have two
• completely different access control lists. Why?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo
Gi

questionData.question:
Two different claims that use the same security profile can have two
completely different access control lists. Why?
questionData.answer:
The security profile generates a list of users based on the criteria. The users who meet
the criteria vary from claim to claim. For example, if a profile says only the claim owner
and members of his group can view and edit the claim, then two claims will have
different access control lists if they are owned by users in different groups.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer [a
Two different claims that use the same security profile can have two
• completely different access control lists. Why?
•
•
The security profile generates a list of users based on the criteria. The users who meet
the criteria vary from claim to claim. For example, if a profile says only the claim owner
and members of his group can view and edit the claim, then two claims will have
different access control lists if they are owned by users in different groups.
